columns.text: The goal of this task is to find the highest exchange ratio Birdie should be willing to pay and still undertake the merger.

The highest exchange ratio Birdie should be willing to pay and still undertake the merger is the one that makes $\operatorname{NPV}$ zero, so no profit or losses are registered from the merger. Let's find this exchange ratio! From the results of the previous task, we know that the price per share of $\$27.83 $makes the $\operatorname{NPV}$ zero. Then, the exchange ratio associated with this share price is: $$ \begin{align*} \text{Exchange ratio} &=\frac{\text { Target share price }}{\text { Acquirer share price }}\\[10pt] &=\frac{\$27.833237875}{\$87}\\[10pt] &= 0.31992227 \end{align*} $$ ***The highest exchange ratio Birdie should be willing to pay and still undertake the merger is $\bold{0.32}$. This means Birdie has to issue $\bold{0.32}$ of its shares for every $\bold{1}$ share of Hybrid (the Target it plans to acquire)***.

***Let's check our results!*** Hybrid has $8$ million stocks, then Birdie would issue: $$8 \text{ million}\times0.31992227 = 2,559378.20 \text{ shares}$$ This offer will be equivalent to a cash offer: $$2,560,000 \text{shares }\times \$87 = \$222,665,903$$ Let's substitute to find the current cash flow: $$ \begin{align*} \text{Current cash flow}&= \$55,000,000 \hspace{3pt}–\hspace{3pt} (\text{Price per share }\times\text{ Shares outstanding})\\[10pt] &= \$55,000,000\hspace{3pt} –\hspace{3pt} \$222,665,903\\[10pt] &= -\$167,665,903 \end{align*} $$ If we go to see Figure 1 (from the results of the previous task), we will realize that this value $-\$167,665,903$ makes the $\operatorname{NPV}$ zero:

Figure 1. NPV calculation with $27.83 stock price.

***Our numbers match!***
